title: The Division of the Land
shortSummary: Ezekiel 48 details the apportioning of the land among the twelve tribes of Israel in the vision of the restored kingdom. It describes the boundaries, the special portions for the sanctuary, priests, Levites, and the prince, and concludes with the naming of the city as 'The LORD is there,' emphasizing God's abiding presence with His people.
timeline: c. 593-571 BC - During the Babylonian exile, Ezekiel's prophetic vision of Israel's future restoration

keyCharacters.name: Tribes of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The twelve tribes receiving their allotted inheritance in the land as described in the vision.

keyCharacters.name: Sons of Zadok
keyCharacters.description: A priestly family set apart for special service, receiving a dedicated holy portion of land.

keyCharacters.name: Levites
keyCharacters.description: The tribe set apart for religious duties, receiving a designated land portion adjacent to the priests.

keyCharacters.name: The Prince
keyCharacters.description: A future leader who receives land adjoining the holy oblation and city, symbolizing governance under God’s rule.

definitions.definition: An offering or gift presented to God, here referring to the sacred land set apart for priests and religious purposes.
An ancient unit of measurement used to describe the dimensions of the land portions.
The holy place or temple where God’s presence dwells, central in the city’s layout.
Common or secular, not holy; here referring to land used for ordinary city dwellings and suburbs.

outline.heading: Allocation of Tribal Portions
outline.description: The chapter opens with a detailed listing of the tribal allotments from north to south, emphasizing the orderly division of the land among Israel’s tribes.

outline.heading: The Holy Oblation and Sanctuary
outline.description: A special portion of land is set aside for the sanctuary and the priests, particularly the sons of Zadok, highlighting the sacred nature of this area and its centrality.

outline.heading: The City and Its Suburbs
outline.description: The dimensions and layout of the city and its suburbs are described, including the land reserved for the Levites and the city dwellers, showing the integration of holy and common spaces.

outline.heading: Land for the Prince and Remaining Tribes
outline.description: The prince receives land adjoining the holy portions, and the remaining tribes receive their inheritance, completing the comprehensive division of the land.

outline.heading: Gates of the City and Its Name
outline.description: The city’s gates are named after the tribes of Israel, symbolizing unity and identity, and the city is named 'The LORD is there,' affirming God’s permanent presence.

application: Trust in God's sovereign plan for His people, knowing He will restore and provide according to His promises.
Recognize the importance of holiness and separation in our lives, as exemplified by the special portions for priests and Levites.
Commit to serving God faithfully, like the sons of Zadok who did not stray, maintaining obedience even when others fall away.
Live with the assurance that God desires to dwell among His people, encouraging us to cultivate His presence in our daily lives.

keyVerses.text: And by the border of Judah, from the east side unto the west side, shall be the offering which ye shall offer of five and twenty thousand reeds in breadth, and in length as one of the other parts, from the east side unto the west side: and the sanctuary shall be in the midst of it.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the centrality of the sanctuary in the land, symbolizing God's presence at the heart of Israel.

keyVerses.text: It shall be for the priests that are sanctified of the sons of Zadok; which have kept my charge, which went not astray when the children of Israel went astray, as the Levites went astray.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes faithfulness and holiness in priestly service, setting a standard for spiritual leadership.

keyVerses.text: It was round about eighteen thousand measures: and the name of the city from that day shall be, The LORD is there.
keyVerses.significance: The naming of the city declares God's abiding presence, a profound promise of His nearness to His people.
